meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>sell</kanji>ing that you've raised (上げ) is the <vocabulary>amount sold</vocabulary> or number of <vocabulary>sales</vocabulary>. Think of a graph going upward, where it's rising as you sell more things.

When the <kanji>sell</kanji>ing is <kanji>cut</kanji>, that means something is <vocabulary>sold out</vocabulary>. You'll see this word a lot in stores (or, hopefully you won't...) in Japan. Look out for it if you're able!

Remember how 手 can mean “doer”? Here, we have a <kanji>sell</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji>. Who might that be? It’s someone who does selling – a <vocabulary>seller</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>vendor</vocabulary>.

売り手 is usually used when talking about sellers versus buyers.
The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>night</kanji> is the current night, aka <vocabulary>tonight</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>East</kanji> <kanji>North</kanji> area of Japan is called <vocabulary>Tohoku</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>Tohoku region</vocabulary>. It was the region hit by the 2011 Tohoku Earthquake. 

This can also mean <vocabulary>northeast region</vocabulary> when talking about China or Japan, but for other countries (and for the compass direction), we'd use 北東.
When you <kanji>decide</kanji> with your <kanji>heart</kanji> you have true <vocabulary>determination</vocabulary>, unlike when you decide with your mind.

You <kanji>enter</kanji> a <kanji>facility</kanji>. So this is your <vocabulary>admission</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>entrance</vocabulary> into that facility. 

入所 is for entering facilities or institutions, often those with names ending in 所, like a 研究所 (research institute). It's also used in prison contexts. You might gain "admission" to prison for not doing your WaniKani reviews, for example, at least in countries ruled by Crabigators...

Remember how 始める means "to begin something"? 始め is its noun version and means "beginning," as in the start of an action or process. に marks a point in time. So 始めに means <vocabulary>in the beginning</vocabulary>. 

始めに can also mean <vocabulary>to begin with</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to start with</vocabulary> when introducing an opening action, like 始めに、ウォーミングアップをしましょう (let's begin with some warm-up exercises).

The <kanji>real</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is the <vocabulary>real thing</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>real deal</vocabulary>. 

If you learned 本 as <kanji>book</kanji> you can also think of this word as the "book thing." What is this book thing? Is it the real version of the book? Is it the real deal? If so, I'll pay you a million.

You know that 乗り has something to do with <kanji>riding</kanji> and that 物 is a <kanji>thing</kanji>. So what is a "riding thing?" Nowadays, at least, that would be a <vocabulary>vehicle</vocabulary>.
When you <kanji>hold</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> you are a <vocabulary>rich person</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>energy</kanji> you hold (持つ) within you is your <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary>s. What kind of feeling is your energy giving you today?

気持ち can refer to your current mood, to a particular emotion inside you, or to physical feelings and sensations. You hear it in phrases like 気持ちいい (feels good), 気持ちわるい (feels gross), or 気持ちが分かる (I understand how you feel).

You are going to <kanji>release</kanji> and <kanji>send</kanji> something out. Imagine this message going out through the sky to everyone around you. You are going <vocabulary>to broadcast something</vocabulary> to the world! 

The する is on there to make this noun a verb. Without the する it would be the noun "broadcast."

A <kanji>language</kanji> about <kanji>thing</kanji>s. This is a confusing one. Just think of it more like someone talking about things, anything, really. Someone who just talks about things is someone who tells stories. So, this word means <vocabulary>tale</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>story</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>legend</vocabulary> (not the Tom Cruise one, though).

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>conflict</kanji> so the vocabulary means <vocabulary>to compete</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to argue</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to quarrel</vocabulary>. Your views conflict with someone else's so you're going to compete with them to see who's right.
You have <kanji>war</kanji> and <kanji>conflict</kanji>. Of course, conflict comes with war, so this word just means <vocabulary>war</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>compete</kanji> to the point of <kanji>conflict</kanji>, you know that this person / entity is your <vocabulary>competition</vocabulary>. Gotta beat out that competition. For example, in order to beat out the competition, WaniKani has a mascot that can eat every other small furry animal that the competition has for their mascot. Case closed.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>transmit</kanji>, but 伝える is mostly used for "transmitting" information, feelings, or messages to someone else. So it means <vocabulary>to convey</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to tell</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to pass down</vocabulary>.

In technical contexts, 伝える can also mean <vocabulary>to transmit</vocabulary>, in the sense that copper transmits heat or air transmits sound.

We <kanji>pass through</kanji> this <kanji>point</kanji> <kanji>together</kanji>. This point is our <vocabulary>common point</vocabulary>. It is where our ideas, philosophies, and bodies pass through each other.

If people work <kanji>together</kanji> on the <kanji>same</kanji> thing, they're working on a <vocabulary>joint</vocabulary> project. They're doing something <vocabulary>collaborative</vocabulary>.

共同 is used when two or more people or groups do something together with a <vocabulary>shared</vocabulary> purpose or responsibility. 共同作業 (collaborative work) means you share tasks with others, for example, and 共同生活 (shared living) means living together with someone, whether it's a partner or a roommate.
When the <kanji>public</kanji> comes <kanji>together</kanji> you have yourself a nice <vocabulary>community</vocabulary> made up of the <vocabulary>public</vocabulary>.
The things you <kanji>together</kanji> <kanji>have</kanji> are the things that are <vocabulary>shared</vocabulary>.

You know that 好 means <kanji>like</kanji> and this vocab word means the same thing: <vocabulary>like</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>!

This word is an adjective in Japanese, so a more literal translation is <vocabulary>likable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>lovable</vocabulary>. Still, it usually sounds more natural to translate it as a verb in English.
If you have a <kanji>friend</kanji> you <kanji>like</kanji>, well, that's true <vocabulary>friendship</vocabulary>!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>become</kanji> so the vocab verb version would be <vocabulary>to become</vocabulary>.

While the kanji version is worth knowing, be aware that you'll usually see this verb written in hiragana.
When you <kanji>become</kanji> <kanji>achievement</kanji>, you have probably gained plenty of <vocabulary>success</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>elderly</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is an <vocabulary>old person</vocabulary> (or an <vocabulary>elderly person</vocabulary>). Don't call a person a 古い人, though. 古い is used for things, not people. Be nice, they're your elders.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
When you are number <kanji>one</kanji> in <kanji>rank</kanji>, you're in <vocabulary>first place</vocabulary>.

If you're at <kanji>neck</kanji> <kanji>rank</kanji> you're in <vocabulary>first place</vocabulary>. Haven't you ever heard the phrase, "neck and neck" when two people in a race are both super close to first place? Just remember that and you'll never forget this word.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>low</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>low</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>low</kanji> is <vocabulary>the lowest</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the minimum</vocabulary>. It's also what you call something when you think it's <vocabulary>the worst</vocabulary> or just plain <vocabulary>terrible</vocabulary>. Try yelling this out when you're disgusted about someone or something.
The <kanji>first</kanji> of something you'll do several or many <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>the first time</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>first</kanji> thing is <vocabulary>the first</vocabulary> thing.

You know 別 means <kanji>separate</kanji>, and the の here shows it's being used as an adjective to describe something. So it's like saying "a <vocabulary>separate</vocabulary> ______," "a <vocabulary>different</vocabulary> ______," or "<vocabulary>another</vocabulary> ______."

If someone asks if you want a <kanji>separate</kanji> knee (に), you'll say <vocabulary>not particularly</vocabulary>. I mean, you've never thought about it, but do you really need more knees? <vocabulary>Not really</vocabulary>...

In this first meaning, 別に is often used on its own, or with a negative verb or adjective, as in 別に長くない (not particularly long).

However, when 別に is used with a positive verb, it often simply means <vocabulary>separately</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>in addition to</vocabulary>. After all, when you have to do something separately, you have to do it in addition to something else. Like learning this meaning in addition to the first one. What a chore!

A <kanji>separate</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is someone who is different from who they were before. I saw you a year ago and you were someone else. Now you're a <vocabulary>different person</vocabulary>, in a good way! You're a <vocabulary>changed man</vocabulary>.

When you say <kanji>separate</kanji> <kanji>separate</kanji>, you're putting things off into their own areas. So 別々 means <vocabulary>separate</vocabulary>. 

Note that this word is typically used in reference to multiple separate items, as opposed to 別の, which refers to a single separate or different thing. It's also used a lot as an adverb with the particle に to mean "separately."
Something that is <kanji>special</kanji> and <kanji>separate</kanji> from the rest is, well, <vocabulary>special</vocabulary>.

You know the kanji means <kanji>profit</kanji>. When you make it into a verb, though, it means <vocabulary>to work well</vocabulary>. If you think about it, when something works well it makes you a profit.

When you <kanji>profit</kanji> from your <kanji>convenience</kanji>, that means you have something very <vocabulary>convenient</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>handy</vocabulary>. Remember, you can profit in other ways besides money. This convenience could be giving you a profit in happiness or extra time as well. All these things are very handy to have.
You <kanji>toil</kanji> and use your <kanji>strength</kanji>. Ugh! How difficult. You really put in a <vocabulary>great effort</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>labor</kanji> <kanji>work</kanji> is when you're doing work with your body, right? That's <vocabulary>manual labor</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Suffering</kanji> and <kanji>labor</kanji>. Sounds like the kind of thing these soft hands wouldn't want to deal with. These are <vocabulary>hardships</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>troubles</vocabulary>. Hopefully you don't have too much of this with kanji anymore!
<kanji>Someone</kanji> who does <kanji>labor</kanji> for <kanji>work</kanji> is a <vocabulary>laborer</vocabulary>.
A vocab made from a single kanji all alone usually keeps at least one of the meanings of its kanji parent. In this case, that's <vocabulary>life</vocabulary>.
Everyone has to <kanji>carry</kanji> their <kanji>fate</kanji>. So what is the thing you're carrying? It's your <vocabulary>fate</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>fate</kanji> <kanji>orders</kanji> are the orders you get from above. You are <vocabulary>order</vocabulary>ed and <vocabulary>command</vocabulary>ed to carry out said orders.
The <kanji>ocean</kanji>/<kanji>sea</kanji> <kanji>coast</kanji> is the <vocabulary>seashore</vocabulary>. Then again, it could also be the <vocabulary>coast</vocabulary> as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>release</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to release</vocabulary>, as in <vocabulary>to set free</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to let something go</vocabulary>.

放す often suggests that you've released something in a way that gives it freedom to move or go where it wants. Think of letting your dog run in the field — it's not just that you let go of the leash, but that the dog is now free to run around as it pleases.

When you <kanji>open</kanji> then <kanji>release</kanji>, say, a door, you're opening it up for everyone to come in. That's why it means <vocabulary>to open something up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to throw something open</vocabulary>.

meanings.meaning: To Open Something To The Public

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is a good way to start stories, by the way: 昔々に… (Long, long ago).

The <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>wave</kanji> is a wave of electricity going through the air. There are many words you can use to describe this, but the easiest one is <vocabulary>reception</vocabulary> (like the reception on your phone, for example).

Other more technical meanings are <vocabulary>radio wave</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>electromagnetic waves</vocabulary>. Which one you like is up to you, but reception is going to be the most common meaning on the street. Luckily people in Japan don't have AT&T, otherwise you'd hear this word a lot more…

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pour</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to pour</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>pour</kanji> your <kanji>ideas</kanji> into something, you're thinking a lot about it. You're paying close <vocabulary>attention</vocabulary> and using <vocabulary>caution</vocabulary>. You'll see this on a lot of <vocabulary>warning</vocabulary> signs marking dangerous things in Japan, so be sure to pay attention to them!

You <kanji>pour</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> onto a form. You're filling out this form to <vocabulary>order</vocabulary> something new for yourself. It's a formal <vocabulary>request</vocabulary> to get this new thing (imagine it being something you're excited about ordering right now, and imagine yourself ordering it by pouring writing onto an order form).

You <kanji>collect</kanji> and focus in on the <kanji>middle</kanji>. Really zoom in on it. When you do this, you're concentrating on this spot, thus making the meaning of this word <vocabulary>to concentrate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to focus</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>raise</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be raised</vocabulary>. 

P.S. This word is for when you are being raised, not when you are doing the raising of someone. That's <vocabulary>育てる</vocabulary>. You'll learn it later.
<kanji>Teach</kanji> and <kanji>nurture</kanji>. That's what your <vocabulary>education</vocabulary> is supposed to do.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pick up</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to pick something up</vocabulary>.
The kanji means <kanji>finger</kanji>. So, if you "to finger" something, what are you doing? You're pointing. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to point</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. The only difference is that this word can mean <vocabulary>finger</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>toe</vocabulary>. What are toes but small, walking fingers?

When you <kanji>determine</kanji> and use your <kanji>finger</kanji> to point at someone or something, you're going <vocabulary>to appoint</vocabulary> them. Just imagine yourself determining who's the best for the job then pointing with your finger. That is who you will appoint. The する on the end makes it a verb, so <vocabulary>指定</vocabulary> would be "appointment" or "designation" or something along those lines. Cool how する works.

<kanji>Western style</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> is just <vocabulary>Western clothing</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>Western style clothes</vocabulary>). But nowadays, because Japanese people wear Western clothing all the time, we use it to just mean <vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary>. We're talking things that aren't kimonos, etc.

A <kanji>Western style</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> is a <vocabulary>Western style room</vocabulary>. We're talking something that's not a tatami mat filled room. Good to know this word if you're staying in hotels or ryokans and prefer not to sleep on a futon, etc.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>way</kanji>/<kanji>road</kanji> of the <kanji>god</kanji>(s) is, as you can probably guess, a big Japanese religion. There's two, and I'll give you a hint, this one isn't Buddhism (that would probably have the kanji for Buddha in it, no?). So what's the other big one? It's <vocabulary>Shinto</vocabulary>. If you're having trouble remembering this because you've never heard of it before, skip to the reading. The reading will help.

A <kanji>God</kanji> <kanji>company</kanji>... think of this as "what 'company' does the god's work?" Well, the answer to that is a shrine, probably. In this case a <vocabulary>Shinto shrine</vocabulary> because of the しん in 神.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well - that is the unit of time, <vocabulary>second</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>tall</kanji> <kanji>grade</kanji> item is really just a <vocabulary>high grade</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>high-class</vocabulary> item.
The <kanji>first</kanji> <kanji>level</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>beginner level</vocabulary>. Compare this to 中級 and 上級 (vocab from this level) to get a fuller understanding.
Something at the <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>level</kanji> or <kanji>grade</kanji> is at an <vocabulary>intermediate level</vocabulary>.
When you are at an <kanji>above</kanji> <kanji>level</kanji>, you are at an <vocabulary>advanced level</vocabulary>. This is referring to things like proficiency in Japanese, or things like that.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>follow</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to follow</vocabulary> (it's also <vocabulary>to chase</vocabulary>, because when you follow something you are chasing it too).

Don't let this word confuse you. It may end in い, but it's not an adjective, it's a noun. There are no rules in war, after all. This word describes what happens in <kanji>war</kanji>. Those things are <vocabulary>battle</vocabulary>s, <vocabulary>fight</vocabulary>s, and <vocabulary>conflict</vocabulary>s.

When you <kanji>make</kanji> <kanji>war</kanji>, you're building it up like you'd build a building. You have to make <vocabulary>strategy</vocabulary>, you have to plan, you have to come up with awesome <vocabulary>tactics</vocabulary> for your <vocabulary>operation</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>war</kanji> <kanji>car</kanji> is probably a little more dangerous than the Honda you drive. No, a war car is a <vocabulary>tank</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>war</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is the <vocabulary>battlefield</vocabulary>. That's where the wars are fought, anyways.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>compete</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to compete</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>good</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>good</vocabulary>.
Something is towards (に) <kanji>special</kanji>. That thing is <vocabulary>especially</vocabulary> special, wouldn't you say?
Something that is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>convenience</kanji> is <vocabulary>inconvenient</vocabulary>.

*Ahem.* This is the <kanji>convenience</kanji> <kanji>facility</kanji>. What place above all others should be convenient to get to? You know, just in case? That would be the <vocabulary>restroom</vocabulary>. You might also call it the <vocabulary>bathroom</vocabulary>, the <vocabulary>toilet</vocabulary>, the lavatory, or the facilities.

This word is casual and can often sound gruff, so you won't normally see it on official signs or hear it in polite conversation. It's worth knowing so you can understand it in casual speaking and writing though.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>work</kanji>, and the verb version means <vocabulary>to work</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to labor</vocabulary>, and sometimes <vocabulary>to commit</vocabulary> (a crime).
The <kanji>idea</kanji> you <kanji>see</kanji> in your head is your <vocabulary>opinion</vocabulary>. As the dude once said... "That's just, like, your 意見, man."

The <kanji>flavor</kanji> of an <kanji>idea</kanji>, what is that? Imagine yourself licking an idea to figure out what it tastes like. What do you think you'll be tasting? Probably the <vocabulary>meaning</vocabulary> of said idea.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

When you <kanji>sell</kanji> something <kanji>cheap</kanji>, you're selling it at a <vocabulary>discount</vocabulary>. Alternatively you can remember this word as <vocabulary>sell cheaply</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bargain sale</vocabulary>. These are good deals!
When you <kanji>return</kanji> the <kanji>doing</kanji>s of another person, you're doing it to <vocabulary>get even</vocabulary> (whether it's a nice thing or a mean thing).

You hopefully know the word 返す, which means "to return" (as in, you're doing the direct action of returning something). This word, on the other hand, is the version where something just returns (and you're not doing the action of returning it). Use the る to help you to remember this. る the Kangaroo is returned to you. You don't do any of the returning, it just happens or someone else does it. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to be returned</vocabulary>.

Note this word is often combined with くる (to come), which reinforces the aspect that something is coming back to you.

What's a <kanji>ride</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji>? It's a <vocabulary>boarding area</vocabulary>! This word is used widely to refer to any place where you board transportation, such as a <vocabulary>bus stop</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>taxi stand</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>train platform</vocabulary>.

You've seen the word 使う hopefully by now. If you have, you know it means "to use." So, the <kanji>way</kanji> to <kanji>use</kanji> something is the <vocabulary>way of using</vocabulary> (aka <vocabulary>how to use</vocabulary>). This will be a word you see when you're looking at directions for how to use something.

You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "thing." So when you're <kanji>doing</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>s all day, what are you probably doing? A <vocabulary>job</vocabulary>! All jobs really just amount to doing things.

Just like "job" in English, 仕事 can refer to a person's specific <vocabulary>occupation</vocabulary>, to <vocabulary>work</vocabulary> in general, or to a particular task depending on the context.

You've hopefully come across 負ける by now, which means "to lose." So, you can figure out this word means "losing dog." Well, calling someone a dog isn't so nice, so you're probably just calling them a <vocabulary>loser</vocabulary>.

You've hopefully seen 勝つ by now, which means "to win." This is a nouny version of that. So, what's the noun version of "to win?" It's <vocabulary>a win</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>victory</vocabulary>.

You've already been introduced to the word 苦しい. That word means painful, or agonizing. So, if you turn that into a verb, you have <vocabulary>to suffer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to struggle</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>attach</kanji> your <kanji>energy</kanji> (imagine someone suddenly looking up at something, attaching their energy to it), you have noticed or realized something. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to realize</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to notice</vocabulary>. 

Don't confuse this with 気を付けて which is similar in that it has all the same kanji. It's just used a little different. Try to remember the difference before moving on.

You know the words 見る and 送る by now, hopefully. Here you're "seeing" the "sending." You're seeing someone off, so this verb is <vocabulary>to see off</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>to put off</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pass on</vocabulary>, since it's as though you're just passively seeing someone (or something) off rather than taking action and going with them.

You know the single word 時, right? It means <kanji>time</kanji>. This is that twice. So you have one time, and you have another time. They are separate. Things don't happen in every of these times you have. They happen <vocabulary>sometimes</vocabulary>.

Imagine someone <kanji>accept</kanji>ing something and then <kanji>attach</kanji>ing something. This person is a <vocabulary>receptionist</vocabulary>, because they are accepting the call, writing down the information, and then attaching said information to a sticky note for you to read. You say, "No, I'm not available."

You've hopefully seen 買う by now and know it means "to buy." So, 買い is going to be similar to that. Add that to <kanji>thing</kanji> and you have a "buying things" sort of word. What does "buying things" describe? It describes <vocabulary>shopping</vocabulary>.

A "suffering hand" is a little misleading. Think more in terms of the words 苦い (bitter) and 手 (person... remember how that happens sometimes?). Now think of this word like you're bitter about having to work with someone. Why? Because they are extremely <vocabulary>hard to deal with</vocabulary>.

Something that's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>good</kanji> is <vocabulary>bad</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>substandard</vocabulary>. This usage is more formal and frequently paired with other kanji compounds. Alternatively, it can refer to someone who is a  <vocabulary>delinquent</vocabulary>, in which case it is often used as a standalone word.

When you have a "feeling" (気持ち) that is "good" (いい), you are <vocabulary>feeling good</vocabulary>.

気持ちいい is what you say when something really <vocabulary>feels good</vocabulary>, both physically and emotionally. You can say it after stepping into a hot bath, feeling a cool breeze, or getting a massage that hits just right. It's the Japanese version of leaning back and going "ahhh, this feels nice!"

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>attempt</kanji> or <kanji>try</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to try something out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to give something a try</vocabulary>. Why don't you try out the meaning of this verb, while you're at it?

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>compare</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to compare</vocabulary>.

For <kanji>school admission</kanji> (入学) you're taking an <kanji>examination</kanji> (試験). What exams do you have to take to get into a school? How about <vocabulary>entrance exam</vocabulary>s? The Japanese ones are pretty hard. Another word for them is "hell tests."
Something <kanji>outside</kanji> your normal <kanji>idea</kanji> of how things work will come as <vocabulary>unexpected</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>surprising</vocabulary> to you.
It is <kanji>correct</kanji> you have <kanji>solve</kanji>d the answer, getting the <vocabulary>correct answer</vocabulary>. You'll see this on Japanese game shows a lot. 正解！！！
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You know that the kanji 付 means <kanji>attach</kanji> and words like 付く mean "to be attached." This has the same idea. When you see this attached to another word, for example, you might know that something is attached to something else, or perhaps <vocabulary>included</vocabulary> with it. For example, if you stay at a hotel room, maybe it is a breakfast付き, i.e. "<vocabulary>including</vocabulary> breakfast."

You like the <kanji>flavor</kanji> of a particular <kanji>direction</kanji>, so you go that way. Everyone else going in the same flavor direction is your <vocabulary>ally</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>supporter</vocabulary>. They're your flavor direction allies. They have the same tastes and they're chasing the same flavors in life, so naturally they become allies, right?

You have 発売, which means "for sale," and then you have 中 which is <kanji>middle</kanji>. An item that is in the middle of being for sale is <vocabulary>now for sale</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>in stores now</vocabulary> or in other words <vocabulary>now available</vocabulary>. You'll see this for items which have recently been released or when a shopkeeper wants to let you know that they're selling something now, finally, or whatever.

An <kanji>eat</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> (aka "a thing you eat") is <vocabulary>food</vocabulary>. Eat those things. Eat that food. Because it's a "thing" you know it's a noun. Interesting how this kanji can turn a verb like this into a noun, right? Look out for it because this pattern will show up with other verbs as well!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
If 丁度 is "exactly", then "exactly good" is going to be just the right amount, aka <vocabulary>just right</vocabulary>.

This is the verb version of 保持 (keep), so this means <vocabulary>to keep</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to hold</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to maintain</vocabulary>.

Note that this is a formal word that's commonly used in professional or official contexts.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>pass through</kanji> but we already know the word 通る which means to pass through. This word means a different kind of passing through, like how you pass through the halls of your school everyday. But we don't say to pass through school, we say <vocabulary>to attend</vocabulary> school, or <vocabulary>to commute</vocabulary> to school.

You'll see this attached to other words... like "sales" or "tennis." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ department, or a ___ club, making this word mean <vocabulary>department</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>club</vocabulary>, similar to the kanji meaning.
<kanji>Above</kanji> the <kanji>roof</kanji> is the <vocabulary>rooftop</vocabulary>. What else would be up there?

This <kanji>task</kanji> is just an <kanji>idea</kanji> because you're still doing <vocabulary>preparation</vocabulary> for it. You're <vocabulary>getting ready</vocabulary>. Once you finish that, the task idea can become a task reality, but until then you're just preparing.

用意 means having something ready for a specific purpose. Meals, cars, rooms, and even umbrellas are all things you might get to a state of readiness with your 用意. And once it's 用意'd, that means it's set and ready to go.

Remember how 欠 means <kanji>lack</kanji>? This verb is related. The 欠かす form is a little tricky, but it's sort of like you're causing yourself to lack something. So it means <vocabulary>to do without</vocabulary>. Depending on the context, it can also mean <vocabulary>to miss an event</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fail to do</vocabulary> something. Just keep in mind this word is most often used in the negative, like 欠かせないもの (things you can't do without) or 朝のコーヒーは欠かさない (never go without morning coffee).

You can remember 欠かす this way: Since you cause yourself to lack something with this word, it's all your fault. That's why you want to <reading>cuss</reading> (かす). You made yourself miss out on something. Well, $*%!!!

If you try to <kanji>see</kanji> a bunch of <kanji>thing</kanji>s at once, you are probably <vocabulary>sightseeing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>watching</vocabulary>. This can also refer to the person doing the action, so it can sometimes mean <vocabulary>sightseer</vocabulary> too.

The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that 予め is mostly used in formal contexts like meetings, announcements or notices, and business emails.
Remember how you learned that 仮名 means "kana?" Well this is <kanji>flat</kanji> kana. Flat kana is just <vocabulary>hiragana</vocabulary>.
Remember how you learned the words 文字 and 通り? Well an "avenue" made of "letters" is <vocabulary>literally</vocabulary> <vocabulary>to the letter</vocabulary>. Wink.
A <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>diagram</kanji> is one that's for everyone to see. It's a <vocabulary>sign</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>first</kanji> thing you <kanji>walk</kanji> through when you learn something new will always be the <vocabulary>basics</vocabulary>. You never start by running, you always have to start slow and work your way through the <vocabulary>ABCs</vocabulary> before you start to run.
This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>new</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>new</vocabulary> too.

Go <kanji>west</kanji> until you encounter <kanji>Western style</kanji> buildings and customs and languages everywhere. Hey, you've made it to <vocabulary>the West</vocabulary>! 

西洋 refers to <vocabulary>Western countries</vocabulary>, especially European and English-speaking countries. It's the same kind of "West" that people mean when they talk about <vocabulary>Western</vocabulary> culture and all that.
One of the kanji meanings is <kanji>side</kanji>, and as a standalone word this also means <vocabulary>side</vocabulary>, as in the sides of a shape.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

When it comes to your <kanji>heart</kanji>, the way you hold (持つ) it determines your <vocabulary>mindset</vocabulary> and your <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary>s.

心持ち is a slightly old-fashioned word for someone's inner state or attitude beneath the surface — kind of like their frame of mind or disposition. In modern usage, it's more commonly used as an adverb to mean "<vocabulary>somewhat</vocabulary>," like 心持ち速く (somewhat fast, just a bit faster).

<kanji>Long ago</kanji> people used to <kanji>talk</kanji> about all sorts of things. Most of them weren't true. Long ago people liked to lie a lot. Now we call those things they talked about <vocabulary>folk tale</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>legend</vocabulary>s.

Learner, if you <kanji>see</kanji> a <kanji>thing</kanji>, then it must be <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary>. You saw it, after all, so of course it's <vocabulary>magnificent</vocabulary>. You only see the <vocabulary>beautiful</vocabulary> things in this world. And that's an <vocabulary>admirable</vocabulary> quality.
Remember how 生物 means "living things?" Well when you <kanji>study</kanji> living things you're studying <vocabulary>biology</vocabulary>.
If you want to <kanji>transmit</kanji> the story of someone's life, you have to <kanji>write down</kanji> all of it in a <vocabulary>biography</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>revolve</kanji>, and the verb version is when you make something revolve. You roll it. That's why this verb is <vocabulary>to roll something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb. That means you roll something else, like a ball. Or, if you're a dung beetle, poop. 💩 Not to be confused with 転がる, which is intransitive, like so many verbs ending in がる.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>advance</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to advance something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to move something forward</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, so you act upon something else. You advance something. You move something forward. Like a school project, or your plans for taking over the world.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lack, and this verb means to lack something. Pretty simple in English, but 欠く is actually kind of advanced and formal in Japanese, so it's mostly just used in writing. Also keep in mind this is a transitive verb, so 欠く takes a direct object — maybe someone lacks knowledge, for example, or you lack concentration. This is a bit different from saying "your concentration is lacking," at least grammatically. (For that, you'd use 欠ける.)

Something happened <kanji>direct</kanji>ly <kanji>before</kanji> this. In other words, it happened <vocabulary>just before</vocabulary> this.

直前 is used to talk about something happening <vocabulary>immediately prior to</vocabulary> something else, like when your date cancels on you just before you were supposed to meet or your doctor tells you not to eat a snack right before bed.
